title: Defining new indicators
text: stated , indicator corresponding internal function package, name, starting dot (.). function implements estimation procedure described indicator definition. general structure internal function : three dots (.e. ...) used ignore additional parameters passed function estimate_indicators(). advantage allowing omission data input parameters used. example show internal function estimation basal area, requires one data frame, stand_dynamic_input, two additional parameters:
code: .[indicator name] <- function(stand_static_input = NULL,                               stand_dynamic_input = NULL,                               plant_static_input = NULL,                               plant_dynamic_input = NULL,                               # [additional param 1],                               # [additional param n],                               ...){ } forestindicators:::.basal_area #> function(plant_dynamic_input = NULL, #>                         min_tree_dbh = 7.5, #>                         tree_state = "live", #>                         ...){ #>  #>   ## Filter plant_dynamic_input by state = "cut" #>   plant_input <- plant_dynamic_input |> #>     dplyr::filter(state == tree_state) #>  #>   ## Compute volume over bark at the tree-level #>   plant_input <- plant_input |> #>     dplyr::filter(dbh >= min_tree_dbh) |> #>     dplyr::mutate(basal_area = n*pi*(dbh/200)^2) #>  #>   ## Summarize at the plot-level #>   df <- plant_input |> #>     dplyr::group_by(id_stand, date) |> #>     dplyr::summarise(basal_area = sum(basal_area)) #>  #>   ## Return the output data frame #>   res <- df |> dplyr::select(id_stand, date, basal_area) #>   return(res) #> } #> <bytecode: 0x60abcaab6780> #> <environment: namespace:forestindicators>
